Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative research: Origin of multicellular complexity in experimentally-evolved Saccharomyces cerevisiae
Award.AbstractNarration:
How did complex multicellular life arise from the single-celled microorganisms that defined life on Earth for billions of years? The rise of multicellular organisms drove a profound diversification of life that fundamentally changed Earth's ecology, yet little is known about how this major evolutionary transition occurred. This is largely due to the fact that most multicellular lineages are ancient, and early steps in this transition have been obscured by extinction. The PIs have overcome this limitation by developing a novel laboratory system, experimentally evolving simple multicellularity in Baker's yeast. Over thousands of generations of laboratory evolution, these cluster-forming 'snowflake yeast' evolve a suite of multicellular adaptations, including larger cluster size, an elevated rate of programmed cell death, and a more hydrodynamic profile. The PIs will use this model system to examine how novel multicellular traits arise in evolution, and will determine whether a fundamental developmental mechanism, the single-celled bottleneck that most multicellular organisms pass through (e.g., a single fertilized egg), improves the ability of natural selection to act on these emergent multicellular traits. This interdisciplinary work utilizes cutting-edge techniques in experimental evolution, next generation sequencing, molecular genetics, confocal microscopy, image analysis, and mathematical modeling. By illuminating the earliest steps in the evolutionary transition to multicellularity, the proposed research will help resolve an outstanding problem of central importance to biology. The evolution of biological complexity remains challenging to teach, particularly at the high school level. This award will support the development of a novel lab module, suitable for both high school and college classes, in which students use snowflake yeast and computer simulations to examine the evolution of multicellularity. The PIs will hold summer on-campus workshops to train teachers in the Atlanta area to use this curricula.

Recent experiments have shown that unicellular organisms readily evolve to form multi-celled clusters, but little is known about how cellular clusters subsequently evolve greater multicellular complexity. The proposed research addresses this subject directly by asking the following questions: How do multicellular traits arise in evolution when mutation and recombination can only directly affect cell-level phenotype? Can early developmental mechanisms evolve to facilitate selection on these emergent multicellular traits? How are genes recruited for developmental functionality, and how are novel multicellular adaptations integrated into overall organism form and function? Answering the above questions will provide fundamental insight into the evolutionary origins of multicellular complexity, and will provide a theoretical foundation for similar investigations in other major evolutionary transitions. Snowflake yeast are an ideal experimental system for this work: the PIs have already evolved substantial morphological novelty, the snowflake growth form is mathematically tractable and has already been modeled by the PIs, and the extensive bioinformatic and molecular genetic tools developed for yeast allows for synthetic construction of multicellular strains with precisely defined properties.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The evolution of multicellular organisms was transformative for the biosphere- without multicellularity, Earth would appear like a wetter, greener version of Mars. Multicellularity has evolved at least 25 times in different lineages, but all known transitions are ancient (hundreds of millions of years old), and little is known about the early steps in this major evolutionary transition.

Through mathematical modeling and experiments with the snowflake yeast model system of undifferentiated multicellularity, we examined how simple clusters of cells evolve increased complexity prior to the evolution of genetically regulated developmental programs. So far, this grant has resulted in 17 papers published or in press, with more in development, including publications in top scientific journals (i.e., PNAS, eLife, Nature Communications, Nature Physics, Current Biology (x2), and Trends in Ecology and Evolution).

This work has resulted in a number of important discoveries.

First, we have shown how biophysical mechanisms help solve the 'problem of multicellular development' for nascent multicellular organisms. Genetically-regulated development plays a key role in multicellularity, directly playing a role in the origin of multicellular traits, and making them heritable. Without development, it is not clear how simple multicellular organisms can undergo adaptive evolution. We show that, prior to the evolution of development, multicellular traits emerge from the physical interactions of cells within the group. For example, to evolve larger size, we show that snowflake yeast evolve more elongate cells, which increases the size to which they can grow before division by reducing cell-cell strain on the cluster interior.

This work demonstrates how multicellular adaptation can proceed prior to the evolution of genetically-regulated development. Further, we show that the heritability of these emergent multicellular traits can be higher than the underlying cell-level trait. Thus, the hierarchal nature of multicellularity (groups composed of many cells) is an advantage for this evolutionary transition, scaffolding the origin of heritable multicellular traits, and solving the 'problem of multicellular development'.

Second, multicellularity organisms can either grow clonally, where every cell is genetically identical, or can form as an aggregate of potentially unrelated cells. Only clonal multicellular organisms have evolved to be complex. This has been thought to be due to problems stemming from cheating in genetically-diverse aggregates, which are avoided in clonally-developing organisms. Aggregative organisms could, in theory, avoid cheating by evolving kin recognition systems, interacting just with clonemates. So why haven't they done this? We show that aggregative multicellular organisms have an ecological advantage over clonal multicellular organisms, both growing faster and forming larger groups with higher survival, but, surprisingly, this advantage is inhibited by strong kin recognition. Thus, the weak recognition mechanisms that exist in aggregative multicellular organisms are probably an adaptive feature, not a bug. Persistent social conflict may be a consequence of this weak kin recognition, however, limiting their ability to evolve complex multicellularity.

Third, we show that reproductive specialization should be able to evolve under a broader set of conditions than previously thought, overturning decades of prior theory. Reproductive specialization (e.g., cellular differentiation into germ and somatic cells) is a hallmark of complex multicellular organisms. A large body of literature, from evolutionary game theory to economic bargaining theory, has shown that complete reproductive specialization should only evolve when the payoff from differentiation accelerates with increased specialization. Indeed, this is considered a fundamental constraint on the evolution of any kind of specialization. Through mathematical modeling, we show that germ-soma differentiation is different from other forms of biological specialization, and as a result, can evolve under a much broader set of conditions, including conditions without accelerating payoffs.

Fourth, we show that the oxygenation of Earth's atmosphere would likely have constrained, not promoted, the evolution of multicellularity. Over an ~800 generation evolution experiment, snowflake yeast under selection for larger size evolved to be much larger when growing without oxygen, or when oxygen was highly abundant, but were constrained at intermediate oxygen conditions. We show that this is because oxygen acts like a resource, and when it is limiting to growth, organisms evolve to be smaller to better use it. This has implications for our understanding of what the geologists call the 'boring billion', 1.8-0.8 billion years ago, when O2 was present at ~1% of modern levels and little was happening in the world of multicellularity.

Through this work, whole genome sequences have been made publicly available. A postdoc, and multiple graduate, undergraduate (including a URM REU student), and high school students were trained in experimental evolution, yeast genetics, bioinformatics, biophysics, and evolutionary theory. We co-organized a two-day, hands-on modeling workshop on evolutionary game theory, which included over 30 students from GT, Spelman College, and UGA. We organized an international conference on the evolution of complex life at Georgia Tech, and we disseminated over 100 DIY snowflake yeast evolution kits, and their associated curricula, to high schools and colleges around the world.
